hawaiian_text: I ia wā, noke aku ana ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka  huhuki ā pau kekahi māla ‘uala ā luna o kekahi  māla ‘uala, pēlā nō ka huhuki ‘ana ā pau nā māla  ‘elua ā kū ke āhua o ka lau o ka ‘uala, he kanahā  āhua ka nui o nā māla ‘elua. A laila, ho‘i a‘ela ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o a hō‘ā i ke ahi a ‘ōhinu akula ‘ehā  ‘au o ka ‘uala i luna o kapuahi e ‘ā ana. Iā ia e  ‘ōhinu ana i luna o ke ahi, ho‘i maila kona makua  kāne kōlea ā hiki, nīnau akula i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī: “‘A‘ole.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “‘Ae, ‘o ke po‘o  ona a me nā maka ka mea e ‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala i  kēia lā, no laila, eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u.”
gpt-4_1_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o persisted in pulling up an entire sweet potato patch and then another sweet potato patch, so that, having pulled up both patches, there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves—the combined total of the two patches was forty mounds. Then, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire, roasting four sweet potato vines on the blazing hearth. While he was roasting them over the fire, his stepfather arrived at last, and asked his mother, Pōka‘ī, a question, to which she replied, “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes: his head and eyes will be the relish for my sweet potatoes today. Therefore, today is the day he dies at my hands.”
gpt-4_1_commentary:
• **Destructive Action & its Allegorical Context:**  
  – The passage opens with Nāmakaokapāo‘o engaged in a relentless uprooting (“huhuki”) of two entire sweet potato (*‘uala*) patches. This degree of destruction—explicitly detailed as “he kanahā āhua” (forty mounds of sweet potato leaves)—invites interpretation beyond mere childish mischief. The act is methodical, not random: the complete stripping of resources points to themes of depletion, perhaps even wastefulness, and the disruption of familial or communal sustenance.
  – In traditional Hawaiian society, sweet potatoes were a staple crop, essential to everyday survival, especially in resource-poor environments or on outer islands such as Ni‘ihau. A child’s destruction of food sources is a grave violation of communal trust and resource management practices; symbolically, it can also signify a rupture in orderly society and a challenge to established authority or protocol.

• **Ritual Hearth, Number Symbolism, and 'Ai Kapu Allusion:**  
  – After his act, Nāmakaokapāo‘o kindles a fire (“hō‘ā i ke ahi”) and roasts (“‘ōhinu”) four vines (“‘ehā ‘au”) on the hearth. The text gives deliberate numerical details: two patches, four vines, forty mounds. The numbers themselves may function as a riddle or mnemonic device, but also hint at deeper layers of meaning:
      * "Kānahā" (forty) in the traditional counting system often signals completeness or the totality of something large, while “‘ehā” (four) carries cosmic and directional associations (the four cardinal points).
      * The action of broiling vine cuttings ('au), rather than the tuber itself, is especially noteworthy—vine cuttings (maka) are used for propagation, so destroying and roasting them eradicates both the present and future food sources (a metaphor for breaking generational continuity or interrupting the ‘āina's cycle).
      * The kapuahi (“hearth”) had ritual significance in Hawaiian homes, serving as the locus for cooking, family gatherings, and sometimes minor ceremonies; thus, Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s actions at the fire may allude to profaning or inverting ritual order.

• **Arrival of the Stepfather and ‘Ai Kapu Inversion:**  
  – The stepfather, Puali‘i, returns and, after inquiry of Pōka‘ī, pronounces a chilling intent: to use the head (“po‘o”) and eyes (“maka”) of Nāmakaokapāo‘o as “‘īna‘i” (relish) for his sweet potato meal, and declares this as the boy’s day to die.
      * The phrase “‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala” refers to the customary eating of a staple (such as sweet potato or poi) with a tasty side dish (often fish or other savory food). Here, Puali‘i substitutes the child’s head and eyes, a shocking reversal.
      * In the context of ‘Ai Kapu (the sacred eating prohibition system), the head of the ulua (trevally) fish, or the head of a human, was sometimes reserved for high chiefs or used in ritual contexts—including sacrifice. Puali‘i’s statement is an inversion of the substitution practiced under ‘Ai Kapu: where a fish (ulua) might be sacrificed or used as ritual food instead of a human, here the human child becomes the substitute for fish, signaling both the gravity of the offense and an escalation of ritual threat to violence.
      * The wordplay on “maka” (eye, bud, or cutting) is significant here: not only does it refer to Nāmakaokapāo‘o's name (“The eyes of the pāo‘o fish”), but also to the life-giving vine cuttings that are being destroyed, thus entwining personal identity, agricultural cycle, and the perpetuation of lineage.

• **Allegorical and Social Implications:**  
  – The passage ultimately explores themes of generational conflict, transition, and the collapse and replacement of ritual systems. Nāmakaokapāo‘o, through wanton destruction but also innovation, challenges the order represented by Puali‘i, a figure explicitly identified with the old authority and ‘Ai Kapu customs.
      * Puali‘i’s resort to violence (“eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u”—today is his day to die at my hands) can be read as the entrenchment of Kapu logic: a system that finds resolution through threat, punishment, and sacrificial violence when order is breached.
      * Yet, in Hawaiian myth and mo‘olelo, such moments often presage transformation. The old must be threatened, even destroyed, for a new order or knowledge (‘ike) to emerge, frequently mediated by the kupuna (ancestors) or the young protagonist endowed with special power or insight.

• **Summary Statement:**  
  – Thus, this passage is rich with encoded cultural and symbolic meaning. On the surface, it is a family conflict over the destruction of crops. At a deeper level, it operates as a metaphor for the tension between old and new, security and innovation, and the continual negotiation of power, resource, and ritual within Hawaiian society. The careful use of names, numbers, and food customs grounds this narrative in the historical realities of the ‘Ai Kapu era and the broader themes of Hawaiian cosmology and social order.

reference_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o was busy tearing  apart the sweet potato patches, yanking them out.  He tore apart both sweet potato patches until  there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves, forty  mounds in all from the two patches. Then  Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire to broil  four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was  broiling the vines, wilting them, his stepfather  came back and reached him and asked   Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s mother, Pōka‘ī, and she said,  “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes, his head and eyes as food  to go with the sweet potatoes that I’ll eat today.  So, today I will kill him.”
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 6:**• The numbers referred to in this paragraph are  interesting and likely a riddle to solve, with esoteric  meaning: 2, 4, 40\. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is a child, but  behaves like a mature adult, albeit destructive and  spiteful, but calculating. This has allegorical meaning  and likely relates to wastefulness and the need to  dismantle ‘Ai Kapu practices.  • Pua-li‘i was so enraged by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s  destruction of the sweet potato patches that he  threatened to eat his head (po‘o) and eyes (nā maka)  with sweet potato in place of ulua fish. The head of  the ulua or of a person likely represents the sweet  potato tuber and the eyes likely represent the sweet  potato vine cutting (maka) that is used to replant and  perpetuate the crop, symbolically, the people of the  land. This also explains the meaning of ʻmaka’ in the  name, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, with ʻpāo‘o’ being used  as a poetic reference to ʻpo‘o’ (head).  – Ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice  on the heiau in the ‘Ai Kapu culture (footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua*: “This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available , probably because of word magic and the meaning of *ulua 2* \[to grow/increase; to be possessed by a god\]. Since an *ulua* replaces a man, *ulua* also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs.”). In this case,  Pua-li‘i threatens to eat the human head and eyes  of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o in place of the ulua: the  opposite of normal ‘Ai Kapu custom. This appears  to allude to Pua-li‘i’s holding on to the ‘Ai Kapu  customs, going back in time allegorically, rather  than forward in time, where humans are no longer  sacrificed in the Western culture. Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o, on the other hand, represents going forward in time, a time of progressive thinking and   abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu;
